header_summary:
A new proposal in the Bitcoin development community introduces a generalized sigops budget, now dubbed the varops budget, to address concerns over denial-of-service attacks through excessive computational time and memory usage in Bitcoin script execution. This varops budget, intricately linked to transaction weight, allocates compute units proportionally, aiming to balance script execution demands before restoring computationally intensive operations. The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) detailing this approach, alongside a prototype for benchmarking script performance under the varops budget constraints, is available for community involvement and feedback ([view the BIP](https://github.com/rustyrussell/bips/blob/guilt/varops/bip-unknown-varops-budget.mediawiki), [check out the GSR prototype](https://github.com/jmoik/bitcoin/tree/gsr)).

In a separate discussion, Brandon Black voices support for LNHANCE, a set of proposed opcodes to enhance Bitcoin script functionality, and an alternative proposal, TEMPLATEHASH+CSFS+IKEY, aimed at modifying legacy script for efficiency gains in certain Lightning Network scenarios. This indicates ongoing efforts within the community to refine Bitcoin's scripting capabilities, showcasing a commitment to technological evolution and adaptability in the cryptocurrency landscape ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/aQzcGITQE3ckHB7K@console/T/#m84900a702c3dc9a737740f8c4439772dec2d4d2a)).

Furthermore, the integration of privacy features into Bitcoin's mining pool structure through a proposed design known as p2share, which leverages MimbleWimble (MW) semantics for enhanced user privacy, is discussed. This design faces challenges in maintaining privacy without compromising the pseudorandom and uniform selection of a shareholder's public key, vital for the equitable distribution of rewards. The discourse suggests adapting consensus rules within the sharechain to preserve privacy, indicating a nuanced approach to incorporating privacy features without detracting from Bitcoin's core principles ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/p2share-how-to-turn-any-network-or-testnet-into-a-bitcoin-miner/2093/3)).

Lastly, the exploration of Simplicity, a programming language for blockchain applications, highlights the strategic incorporation of side effects such as the Failure and Reader effects to enhance computational expressions. This development signifies an advancement in making blockchain applications more efficient and scalable, with a focus on maintaining the purity principles of the Simplicity language while extending its functional scope ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/delving-simplicity-part-two-side-effects/2091)).

active_posts.title: Comparing the performance of ECDSA signature validation in OpenSSL vs. libsecp256k1 over the last decade
active_posts.summary:

- Recent efforts aim to enhance OpenSSL's performance for the secp256k1 curve, indicating a growing emphasis on optimized cryptographic support.

today_in_history_posts.summary:

- Such a cartel could enforce its rule through a soft fork, limiting mining to its members.
- The challenge lies in preventing collusion among miners to protect Bitcoin's security and integrity.
